text:
Totally agree, useful content is the way to go, especially at the bottom of the funnel.

The part that I find hard is top-of-funnel content that’s relevant and useful like this. A lot of the best terms are really hard to rank for, so even if you build a great piece of content, it’s tough to get much traction on it.

Any thoughts/tips for that?

elements.text:
Totally agree, useful content is the way to go, especially at the bottom of the funnel.

The part that I find hard is top-of-funnel content that’s relevant and useful like this. A lot of the best terms are really hard to rank for, so even if you build a great piece of content, it’s tough to get much traction on it.

Any thoughts/tips for that?

text:
Thanks for your contribution <@U029CTQ5X6Y>.

For ToFu content, I agree that it might be difficult to rank for those especially if you're in a competitive niche.

This is because, there are more established competitors, who're looking to grab the top spot on Google like you.

I think in cases like that, it might make more sense to target long tail keywords related to that ToFu content you want to rank for.

For instance, instead of targeting the broad term "ecommerce seo", you can narrow it down to something like "ecommerce seo best practices" or "ecommerce seo for product pages"

You can as well build topic clusters related to that keyword, so you can establish topical authority for it.

Hope this helps.

elements.text:

text: Topic clusters has been my go-to strategy. Makes sense, thanks!

elements.text: Topic clusters has been my go-to strategy. Makes sense, thanks!
